Better <FI>is<Fi> a dry morsel, and quietness therewith, than an house full of sacrifices <FI>with<Fi> strife.<RF>sacrifices: or, good cheer<Rf><CM>
A wise servant shall have rule over a son that causeth shame, and shall have part of the inheritance among the brethren.<CM>
The fining pot <FI>is<Fi> for silver, and the furnace for gold: but the LORD trieth the hearts.<CM>
A wicked doer giveth heed to false lips; <FI>and<Fi> a liar giveth ear to a naughty tongue.<CM>
Whoso mocketh the poor reproacheth his Maker: <FI>and<Fi> he that is glad at calamities shall not be unpunished.<RF>unpunished: Heb. held innocent<Rf><CM>
Children's children <FI>are<Fi> the crown of old men; and the glory of children <FI>are<Fi> their fathers.<CM>
Excellent speech becometh not a fool: much less do lying lips a prince.<RF>Excellent…: Heb. A lip of excellency<Rf><RF>lying…: Heb. a lip of lying<Rf><CM>
A gift <FI>is as<Fi> a precious stone in the eyes of him that hath it: whithersoever it turneth, it prospereth.<RF>a precious…: Heb. a stone of grace<Rf><CM>
He that covereth a transgression seeketh love; but he that repeateth a matter separateth <FI>very<Fi> friends.<RF>seeketh: or, procureth<Rf><CM>
A reproof entereth more into a wise man than an hundred stripes into a fool.<RF>entereth…: or, aweth more a wise man, than to strike a fool an hundred times<Rf><CM>
An evil <FI>man<Fi> seeketh only rebellion: therefore a cruel messenger shall be sent against him.<CM>
Let a bear robbed of her whelps meet a man, rather than a fool in his folly.<CM>
Whoso rewardeth evil for good, evil shall not depart from his house.<CM>
The beginning of strife <FI>is as<Fi> when one letteth out water: therefore leave off contention, before it be meddled with.<CM>
He that justifieth the wicked, and he that condemneth the just, even they both <FI>are<Fi> abomination to the LORD.<CM>
Wherefore <FI>is there<Fi> a price in the hand of a fool to get wisdom, seeing <FI>he hath<Fi> no heart <FI>to it<Fi>?<CM>
A friend loveth at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.<CM>
A man void of understanding striketh hands, <FI>and<Fi> becometh surety in the presence of his friend.<RF>understanding: Heb. heart<Rf><CM>
He loveth transgression that loveth strife: <FI>and<Fi> he that exalteth his gate seeketh destruction.<CM>
He that hath a froward heart findeth no good: and he that hath a perverse tongue falleth into mischief.<RF>He that hath a froward…: Heb. The froward of heart<Rf><CM>
He that begetteth a fool <FI>doeth it<Fi> to his sorrow: and the father of a fool hath no joy.<CM>
A merry heart doeth good <FI>like<Fi> a medicine: but a broken spirit drieth the bones.<RF>like: or, to<Rf><CM>
A wicked <FI>man<Fi> taketh a gift out of the bosom to pervert the ways of judgment.<CM>
Wisdom <FI>is<Fi> before him that hath understanding; but the eyes of a fool <FI>are<Fi> in the ends of the earth.<CM>
A foolish son <FI>is<Fi> a grief to his father, and bitterness to her that bare him.<CM>
Also to punish the just <FI>is<Fi> not good, <FI>nor<Fi> to strike princes for equity.<CM>
He that hath knowledge spareth his words: <FI>and<Fi> a man of understanding is of an excellent spirit.<RF>an…: or, a cool<Rf>
Even a fool, when he holdeth his peace, is counted wise: <FI>and<Fi> he that shutteth his lips <FI>is esteemed<Fi> a man of understanding.<CM>
